os passageiros nos autocarros, uma solução que se destina não só aos utentes, que procuram alternativas aos transportes lotados, mas também ao operador,  que  ajusta  instantaneamente  a  oferta  à procura dos seus serviços 55 . Em Braga, a IA está a ser usada  num  projeto  piloto para ajudar a detetar estacionamento ilegal nas paragens de autocarro 56 . E há várias iniciativas globais para melhorar a eficiência dos autocarros convencionais e oferecer um serviço conveniente aos utilizadores: a Optibus, por exemplo, lançou uma solução de otimização pontual baseada em  IA  para  ajudar  os  operadores  de  transp ortes públicos  a  reduzir  atrasos  e  fornecer  um  serviço pontual 57 e  o  sistema  baseado  em  IA  utilizado  pela rede  de  transportes  públicos  de  Singapura  ajusta dinamicamente os horários dos autocarros com base em dados em tempo real 58 . Outra área em que a IA tem mostrado grandes potencialidades diz respeito à localização automática de veículos (AVL) para melhorar a eficiência dos transportes públicos, gerir operações e melhorar a qualidade dos serviços. Este sistema  usa  sinais  GPS  para  localizar  veículos  em tempo real, detetar problemas, informar os veículos sobre alterações e gerir rotas alternativas. Além disso, fornece informações  aos passageiros através de appsarti nos seus dispositivos móveis 59 . Um exemplo de sistema AVL com GPS é o iBus em Londres . Estes 60 sistemas AVL são potencialmente melhorados com a integração de técnicas de aprendizagem automática que permitem melhorar a gestão da rede de transportes,  seja  no  planeamento  de  horários  de autocarros 61 , seja no desenho de novas rotas e a

programação dos autocarros e na previsão de futura procura  de  passageiros  nas  paragens  e  rotas  de autocarro 62 . De referir ainda um estudo, em que os autores  exploram  formas  de  prever,  em  tempo  real, quantas  pessoas  estão  à  espera  nas  paragens  de autocarro e quantos passageiros estão a bordo. Esta informação  é  muito  útil  para  os  operadores,  pois permite-lhes gerir as viagens de forma mais eficiente. Além disso, ajuda os utilizadores a escolher a melhor rota durante as horas de maior trânsito 63 .
content_en:
Autonomous vehicles: AI has opened entirely new levels of cooperation between various road users. AI is one of the main drivers and enablers of autonomous vehicles, that is, vehicles capable of moving without the support and guidance of a human driver. Despite the challenges they still present to individual rights to autonomy, health, physical integrity, or privacy, automated vehicles offer many benefits, such as increased road safety, reduced congestion and travel times, and lower emissions, as well as greater fuel efficiency. It is expected that autonomous vehicles will significantly change the way transportation systems operate worldwide, as well as alter people's travel patterns, resulting in different social structures and urban forms. Autonomous vehicles are composed of two main components: hardware and software. The hardware includes actuators, sensors, and a computer system, while the software covers navigation modules, localization algorithms, and moving object detection systems. These vehicles use sensor and vehicle-to-vehicle communication technologies to operate safely, avoiding obstacles and pedestrians, thanks to artificial intelligence and 3D cameras. The technology is also being applied to the creation of automated buses, such as Olli, iBus, or Alpha Bus. In other words, AI technologies are used in virtually all components of the system that enable vehicle driving automation. Data collected through cameras, radar, LiDAR, and the vehicle's control system are used by AI systems to understand the physical environment around the vehicle, predict incidents, and advise the driver or take action. AI technologies include computer vision to interpret images and deep learning and neural networks to improve training algorithms and perform virtual tests to enhance the vehicle's responsiveness. Some of these technologies only take on certain driving functions (such as parking or driver assistance), while others are intended to completely dispense with a driver, although, for now, their availability to the general public still seems distant.

Driver supervision and assistance: AI systems integrated into vehicles may include certain features that allow them to recognize certain driver behaviors or emotions, analyzing data from cameras inside vehicles to identify risky behaviors, such as drowsiness and distraction, alerting drivers to avoid accidents.

Accident detection and management: Timely identification of the time, location, and severity of an accident is a long-standing ambition, not only to protect people and property but also to help traffic managers reduce congestion. Neural network-based algorithms that use sensor data on roads to measure traffic flow before and after an incident can help in this regard, overcoming the limitations of statistical techniques. There are several examples of neural network algorithms tested to detect accidents on highways or the presence of objects in real time. Advanced AI systems with the ability to recognize the environment and obstacles around them help mitigate road accident risks. At the same time, some systems can identify and communicate the existence of incidents, their location, and severity, enabling a quick and effective emergency response.

Accident prediction: AI can be decisive in preventing urban road accidents and reducing their impacts. Since the causes of accidents vary by location and time, AI can analyze spatial and temporal patterns in accident databases and identify trends for which mitigation strategies can be created. For example, one study used a neural network to predict the risk of traffic accidents by analyzing spatial and temporal patterns in a database of accidents in Beijing, China, and the results showed that this method was effective and could be used to alert people to dangerous locations. In another study, the authors found that machine learning techniques can identify valuable hidden patterns in historical accident data. In the United Arab Emirates, AI was used to study the factors most associated with the fatal severity of an accident. Solutions are also being developed to help people measure the safety level of roads and locations. For example, there are models that use data from cyclists to estimate a safety score for roads by analyzing images to detect potential hazards for cyclists.

License plate recognition: AI-based license plate recognition is widely used for traffic law enforcement, traffic flow analysis, toll systems, or for recovering stolen vehicles.

Optimization of public road transport: AI can bring many benefits to the management and users of public transport, enabling real-time monitoring of demand needs, automated route optimization, or monitoring compliance with public service obligations.

The prediction of passenger demand in public transport based on previous travel data and environmental information has become even more efficient with access to large volumes of data and artificial neural networks, enabling effective processes for selecting pick-up points. The ant colony algorithm has been proposed to manage bus schedules, efficiently and reliably optimizing driver scheduling, as well as the proposal that artificial neural networks can help reduce passenger waiting times by predicting bus arrival times. In Hong Kong, ScanVIS, the largest public road transport operator in Hong Kong, uses 5G and AI to count passengers on buses in real time, a solution aimed not only at users seeking alternatives to crowded transport but also at the operator, who instantly adjusts supply to the demand for its services. In Braga, AI is being used in a pilot project to help detect illegal parking at bus stops. There are also several global initiatives to improve the efficiency of conventional buses and offer a convenient service to users: Optibus, for example, launched a punctuality optimization solution based on AI to help public transport operators reduce delays and provide on-time service, and the AI-based system used by Singapore's public transport network dynamically adjusts bus schedules based on real-time data. Another area where AI has shown great potential concerns automatic vehicle location (AVL) to improve public transport efficiency, manage operations, and improve service quality. This system uses GPS signals to locate vehicles in real time, detect problems, inform vehicles about changes, and manage alternative routes. In addition, it provides information to passengers through apps on their mobile devices. An example of an AVL system with GPS is iBus in London. These AVL systems are potentially improved with the integration of machine learning techniques that allow for better network management, whether in bus schedule planning, designing new routes, and scheduling buses, or predicting future passenger demand at bus stops and routes. It is also worth mentioning a study in which the authors explore ways to predict, in real time, how many people are waiting at bus stops and how many passengers are on board. This information is very useful for operators, as it allows them to manage trips more efficiently. In addition, it helps users choose the best route during peak hours.
learning_objective: Explain how artificial intelligence technologies are applied within passenger transport systems—such as autonomous vehicles, driver assistance, accident management, and public transport optimization—and describe their main components, benefits, and associated challenges.
description: This lecture explores the transformative impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) on passenger transport, focusing on its application in autonomous vehicles, driver supervision, accident detection and prediction, license plate recognition, and the optimization of public road transport systems. Participants will learn how AI technologies—such as computer vision, deep learning, and neural networks—enable vehicle automation, enhance road safety, optimize bus schedules, predict passenger demand, and support real-time operations in public transport networks. The session examines real-world examples like automated buses, AI-driven accident management, and advanced solutions deployed in cities such as Hong Kong and London. Ethical considerations are highlighted, including the ongoing challenges autonomous vehicles pose to individual rights and privacy, and the balance between technological innovation and the protection of public interests.
lecture_outline: AI enables autonomous vehicles to operate without human drivers, offering benefits like increased road safety, reduced congestion and emissions, and greater fuel efficiency, but also presenting challenges to individual rights such as autonomy and privacy.

Autonomous vehicles consist of hardware (actuators, sensors, computer system) and software (navigation modules, localization algorithms, moving object detection), using technologies like computer vision, deep learning, and vehicle-to-vehicle communication to operate safely.
AI-powered driver assistance systems monitor driver behavior (e.g., drowsiness, distraction) using in-vehicle cameras to identify risks and alert drivers to prevent accidents.

AI algorithms, including neural networks, are used for accident detection, management, and prediction by analyzing sensor and accident data to identify incidents, assess severity, and anticipate high-risk locations.

AI optimizes public transport by enabling real-time demand monitoring, route and schedule optimization, passenger counting, and automatic vehicle location, resulting in improved efficiency, reduced waiting times, and better service quality.

module_pt: IA NA MOBILIDADE E DOS TRANSPORTES
module_en: AI IN MOBILITY AND TRANSPORTATION
content_pt:
O transporte rodoviário de mercadorias é, porventura, das áreas onde o impacto da IA pode ser mais significativo,  permitindo  melhorar  a  eficiência  dos processos, através de recursos de previsão, de forma a impulsionar um fluxo de automação inteligente 64 .

Entre as principais aplicações, podemos destacar:

Veículos autónomos: Também  no  transporte de mercadorias se verifica a possibilidade de transporte sem condutor.  A  tecnologia  atual  já  permite  operar camiões automatizados, oferecendo grandes economias de custos para empresas e consumidores 65 . Um estudo do International Transport Forum descreve quatro cenários. O Cenário Base  prevê  zero  adoção  de  camiões  sem  condutor nas próximas duas décadas. O Cenário Conservador assume a introdução gradual da tecnologia a partir de 2030,  em  mercados  de  long a  distância  e  algumas cidades. O Cenário Regulamentado prevê a permissão desta tecnologia em rotas de longa distância  desde  2028  e  em  cidades  desde  2030.  O

Cenário  Disruptivo assume  a  implementação  da tecnologia  em  rotas  de  longa  distância  a  partir  de 2021 e em cidades desde 2022 66 .

Gestão de Frotas inteligente: Com a integração da IA, os veículos  de transporte rodoviário de mercadorias transformamse  em  pontos  de  dados  avançados, desempenhando um papel central no ecossistema de gestão de frotas. Esta tecnologia permite aos gestores monitorizar  não  apenas  a  localização  dos  veículos, mas também uma ampla gama de fatores e métricas das  desl ocações em tempo real. Além disso, os veículos inteligentes reduzem  a necessidade de comunicação constante entre condutores e gestores, facilitando a operação e tornandoa mais eficiente 67 .

Otimização da entrega em última milha ( last mile ): A última milha é o passo final do processo de entrega de mercadorias e implica o transporte do último centro de  transporte  para  o  seu  destino  final.  Apesar  de representar  uma  distância  relativamente  curta  do percurso total, as entregas em última milha, sobretudo em meio urbano, são marcadas por atrasos e diversos obstáculos, constituindo cerca de 53% do tempo total dos envios.

O desenvolvimento de redes de logística que utilizem IA, nomeadamente na otimização de rotas e previsão de obstáculos em tempo real permite otimizar estes processos 68 .

' Platooning ' de camiões: A IA também torna possível o acoplamento de vários veículos pesados de mercadorias a uma distância mínima uns dos outros ( platooning ) 69 , permitindolhes acelerar ou travar automática e simultaneamente. Enquanto o veículo

content_en:
Road freight transport is perhaps one of the areas where the impact of AI can be most significant, allowing for improved process efficiency through predictive resources, in order to drive an intelligent automation flow.

Among the main applications, we can highlight:

Autonomous vehicles: Also in freight transport, the possibility of driverless transport is being observed. Current technology already allows for the operation of automated trucks, offering significant cost savings for companies and consumers. A study by the International Transport Forum describes four scenarios. The Base Scenario predicts zero adoption of driverless trucks in the next two decades. The Conservative Scenario assumes the gradual introduction of the technology starting in 2030, in long-distance markets and some cities. The Regulated Scenario foresees the permission of this technology on long-distance routes from 2028 and in cities from 2030.

The Disruptive Scenario assumes the implementation of the technology on long-distance routes from 2021 and in cities from 2022.

Intelligent Fleet Management: With the integration of AI, road freight transport vehicles become advanced data points, playing a central role in the fleet management ecosystem. This technology allows managers to monitor not only the location of vehicles, but also a wide range of factors and metrics of trips in real time. In addition, smart vehicles reduce the need for constant communication between drivers and managers, facilitating operation and making it more efficient.

Last mile delivery optimization: The last mile is the final step in the goods delivery process and involves transporting from the last transport hub to its final destination. Although it represents a relatively short distance of the total route, last mile deliveries, especially in urban environments, are marked by delays and various obstacles, accounting for about 53% of the total shipping time.

The development of logistics networks that use AI, particularly in route optimization and real-time obstacle prediction, allows these processes to be optimized.

Truck platooning: AI also makes it possible to couple several heavy freight vehicles at a minimal distance from each other (platooning), allowing them to accelerate or brake automatically and simultaneously. While the lead heavy freight vehicle is driven by a human driver, the drivers of the following vehicles may only be present in complex traffic situations (such as roundabouts), unexpected incidents, or driving within urban centers.
learning_objective: Explain how AI applications—such as autonomous vehicles, intelligent fleet management, last mile delivery optimization, and truck platooning—are transforming road freight transport processes and contributing to increased efficiency in urban mobility systems.
description: This lecture explores the transformative applications of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in road freight transport, highlighting areas where AI drives significant efficiency and automation. Key topics include the emergence of autonomous vehicles and driverless trucks, intelligent fleet management systems that enable real-time monitoring and data-driven decision-making, optimization of last mile delivery through AI-based route planning, and truck platooning technologies that enhance safety and operational efficiency. The lecture presents real-world scenarios and projections for the adoption of these technologies, illustrating how AI is reshaping freight logistics, reducing costs, and addressing challenges in urban and long-distance transport.
lecture_outline: AI enables significant efficiency improvements in road freight transport through predictive resource allocation and intelligent automation.
Autonomous vehicles in freight transport, including driverless trucks, offer potential cost savings and are being introduced in varying scenarios depending on market and regulatory conditions.

Intelligent fleet management with AI allows real-time monitoring of vehicle locations and trip metrics, reducing the need for constant driver-manager communication and increasing operational efficiency.

AI-driven last mile delivery optimization addresses urban delivery challenges by enhancing route planning and real-time obstacle prediction, reducing delays that account for over half of shipping time.

Truck platooning, supported by AI, enables multiple freight vehicles to travel closely together with synchronized acceleration and braking, improving transport efficiency while maintaining human oversight in complex situations.

Gestão de tráfego: Os sistemas de gestão de tráfego baseados  em  IA  surgiram  como  uma  tecnologia fundamental para a modernização das infraestruturas urbanas. Algoritmos  genéticos  também  têm sido  aplicados  para  controlar  automaticamente  os sinais de trânsito nos cruzamentos. Um caso prático é o sistema ITS ' NeverStop ',  que  utilizou  sensores

Sensores IoT recolhem dados em tempo real sobre o desempenho de equipamentos, e algoritmos de IA analisam esses dados para identificar padrões e anomalias, prevendo falhas.

Com machine learning ,  esses  algoritmos  tornam-se mais precisos. A IA Generativa , como o GPT -4, pode

analisar dados não estruturados, prever falhas e automatizar processos de manutenção. content_en:
Traffic management: AI-based traffic management systems have emerged as a fundamental technology for the modernization of urban infrastructures. These systems aim to alleviate congestion and improve the driving experience through a variety of technologies and communication systems, offering significant improvements in terms of safety, efficiency, and congestion reduction by collecting real-time data. By processing data from sensors embedded in roads, cameras, and other IoT devices, AI enables traffic sensors to become intelligent agents, capable of identifying traffic risk issues before they occur, adjusting signal timings, and notifying users about alternative routes and accidents. They capture relevant data that can be integrated into machine learning technology. For example, deep learning approaches have been used to optimize traffic control policies in real time in large-scale systems. Genetic algorithms have also been applied to automatically control traffic lights at intersections. A practical case is the ITS 'NeverStop' system, which used RFID sensors and proved effective in reducing average vehicle waiting times. Another project, 'iLU', aims to improve mobility in Lisbon by analyzing data from car and public transport circulation, seeking to discover circulation patterns in the city, anticipate problems, and make recommendations to the Lisbon City Council so it can improve the management and operation of mobility for people and vehicles in the city. Not only can the municipality improve planning for city circulation in the event of construction, accidents, or major events, for example, but people can also choose the best alternative to move around the city.

In addition, artificial neural networks have shown great potential in traffic light control, managing roads more efficiently based on simulated microscopic data, allowing not only more effective traffic light control but also the prediction of future traffic congestion.

Traffic prediction: Intelligent prediction systems use historical data from road sensors, which are processed by machine learning and AI algorithms to make real-time, short- and long-term forecasts. For example, demographic and geographic data can be used to predict future mobility demand. This demand estimate is important for making decisions about planning and the future techniques most needed to manage a more effective transport system.

Parking management: AI facilitates parking management, and its adoption by parking lot and space operators can simplify and improve operations. AI-equipped camera systems are able to identify vehicles in circulation as well as available spaces, allowing the construction of a real-time map of available spaces and helping drivers find parking easily, reducing search time and frustration.

Predictive maintenance and asset management: The trend is consolidating to move from corrective or preventive maintenance to predictive maintenance, with the goal of reducing overall maintenance costs. IoT sensors collect real-time data on equipment performance, and AI algorithms analyze this data to identify patterns and anomalies, predicting failures.

With machine learning, these algorithms become more accurate. Generative AI, such as GPT-4, can analyze unstructured data, predict failures, and automate maintenance processes. In addition, it offers assistance in the decision-making process and facilitates predictive maintenance in environments where sensors and IoT are limited. By monitoring the condition of buses, for example, it is possible to predict failures and ensure that buses do not interrupt their service, contributing to better transport reliability and increasing passenger confidence and experience. A Portuguese company, headquartered in Coimbra, recently announced a strategic collaboration with SBS Transit to increase the reliability of public transport in Singapore through the implementation of predictive maintenance technology across the entire bus fleet. This project will minimize bus downtime, reduce operating costs, and improve the passenger experience.
learning_objective: Explain how AI-based traffic management, prediction, parking, and predictive maintenance systems function within urban infrastructure modernization, highlighting their roles in improving efficiency, safety, and mobility operations.
description: This lecture explores the transformative role of AI-based systems in urban mobility infrastructures, focusing on their application in traffic management, traffic prediction, parking management, and predictive maintenance. Participants will examine how AI technologies—such as machine learning, deep learning, and genetic algorithms—process real-time data from sensors and IoT devices to optimize traffic flow, reduce congestion, and enhance road safety. Practical case studies, including the ITS 'NeverStop' and 'iLU' projects, illustrate how intelligent systems can anticipate risks, adjust traffic signals, and support urban planning decisions. The lecture also covers the integration of AI in parking solutions and predictive maintenance, highlighting the impact of real-time monitoring and generative AI in reducing operational costs and improving reliability in public transport. This session provides urban mobility planners and related professionals with a foundational understanding of how AI-driven infrastructures contribute to safer, more efficient, and user-centric mobility systems.
lecture_outline: AI-based traffic management systems use real-time data from sensors, cameras, and IoT devices to alleviate congestion, improve safety, and optimize traffic flow by identifying risks, adjusting signals, and notifying users.

Machine learning techniques, such as deep learning and genetic algorithms, enable dynamic optimization of traffic control policies and automatic traffic light management, as demonstrated by systems like ITS 'NeverStop' and 'iLU' in Lisbon.
AI-driven traffic prediction leverages historical, demographic, and geographic data to generate real-time and long-term forecasts, supporting effective transport planning and mobility management.
AI-powered parking management uses cameras and sensors to map available spaces in real time, simplifying parking operations and reducing search time for drivers.

Predictive maintenance systems analyze real-time equipment data with AI algorithms to detect patterns, predict failures, and automate maintenance, minimizing downtime and costs while improving transport reliability and passenger experience.

content_pt:
Os sistemas de mobilidade partilhada, seja de automóveis (como as plataformas TVDE), bicicletas ou  trotinetes,  exponenciados  pelo  surgimento  de aplicações móveis, vieram aumentar a capacidade de recolher  grandes  quantidades  de  dados,  que  a  IA pode utilizar para prever a procura de passageiros de forma eficaz e evitar viagens em vazio, o que ajuda a reduzir o congestionamento e o consumo de energia e  de  combustível.  E  de  facto,  os  prestadores  de serviços de mobilidade desenvolvem algoritmos complexos assente s em IA que permitem o funcionamento  eficiente  de  redes  e serviços de carpooling , partilha de veículos ou de outros meios de transporte.

Matching entre utilizadores e veículos: os algoritmos de IA permitem a combinação rápida e eficaz entre os utilizadores  e  veículos  ou  condutores  disponíveis, reduzindo  os  tempos  de  espera  e  melhorando  a eficiência  do  serviço.  Para  além  da  otimização  de

rotas observada em serviços como os da Lyft 80 , este processo de matching é um componente fundamental para melhorar e personalizar a experiência do utilizador 81 .

Gestão  de  operações  eficiente:  Ferramentas  de  IA permitem aos operadores de sistemas de mobilidade partilhada com condutores planear os itinerários de forma  eficiente,  estimar  com  precisão  o  tempo  de viagem, incluindo as horas de recolha e de entrega, bem como prever e gerir eventuais eventos que gerem aumentos ou reduções espontâneas da procura ou da oferta 82 . Um  estudo  permitiu  prever  a  procura  de serviços de táxi em Tóquio, utilizando redes neuronais.  Os  dados  foram  recolhidos  a  partir  do sistema Taxi Probe, onde os táxis estavam equipados com  sensores  que  registam  informações  como  a localização. Os resultados mostraram que os dados históricos de procura de 4 horas proporcionaram uma melhor  precisão  de  previsão 83 .  Igualmente,  podem sugerir destinos aos condutores com base no histórico  de  viagens  dos  utilizadores  e  introduzir preços  dinâmicos  que  se  adaptem  aos  montantes que previsivelmente os utilizadores estão dispostos a pagar,  considerando  o  destino,  a  hora  do  dia  e  a localização. Além disso, as plataformas podem utilizar IA para identificar e impedir atividades fraudulentas por parte dos condutores.

- » Otimização dos serviços de car-sharing : O futuro da mobilidade  partilhada  inclui  carros  sem  condutor, que utilizam IA e tecnologias de sensores. Estas frotas autónomas  são  mais  rentáveis  e  poderão  substituir até 6,2 milhões de condutores em todo o mundo até

No  caso  dos  sistemas  de car-sharing sem motorista,  os  sistemas  de  IA  podem  ser  utilizados para  prever  as  necessidades  de  carregamento  e/ou manutenção  dos  veículos  partilhados,  garantindo  a fiabilidade e a segurança dos utilizadores, e reduzindo os  tempos  de  paragem  inesperados 85 , bem  como auxiliar  as  cidades  a  distribuir  adequadamente  os veículos pelo território 86 .

Preços dinâmicos: A IA nas plataformas de mobilidade, como TVDE, tem permitido a implementação de sistemas de preços dinâmicos 87 . Estes sistemas ajustam automaticamente os preços das viagens em tempo real, com base na procura, tráfego, condições meteorológicas e disponibilidade de veículos. A utilização de algoritmos de IA permite otimizar a distribuição de veículos, garantindo que a oferta responde rapidamente às flutuações da procura. Adicionalmente, a IA analisa grandes volumes de dados para prever momentos de pico de procura, ajustando proativamente os preços e assegurando uma alocação mais eficiente dos recursos disponíveis.
content_en:
Shared mobility systems, whether cars (such as TVDE platforms), bicycles, or scooters, boosted by the emergence of mobile applications, have increased the ability to collect large amounts of data, which AI can use to effectively predict passenger demand and avoid empty trips, helping to reduce congestion and energy and fuel consumption. In fact, mobility service providers develop complex AI-based algorithms that enable the efficient operation of carpooling networks and services, vehicle sharing, or other means of transportation.

Matching between users and vehicles: AI algorithms enable quick and effective matching between users and available vehicles or drivers, reducing waiting times and improving service efficiency. In addition to route optimization seen in services like Lyft 80, this matching process is a fundamental component for improving and personalizing the user experience 81.

Efficient operations management: AI tools allow operators of shared mobility systems with drivers to efficiently plan itineraries, accurately estimate travel time, including pick-up and drop-off times, as well as predict and manage potential events that generate spontaneous increases or decreases in demand or supply 82. One study was able to predict taxi service demand in Tokyo using neural networks. Data was collected from the Taxi Probe system, where taxis were equipped with sensors that record information such as location. The results showed that 4-hour historical demand data provided better prediction accuracy 83. Likewise, they can suggest destinations to drivers based on users' travel history and introduce dynamic pricing that adapts to the amounts users are likely willing to pay, considering destination, time of day, and location. In addition, platforms can use AI to identify and prevent fraudulent activities by drivers.

- » Optimization of car-sharing services: The future of shared mobility includes driverless cars, which use AI and sensor technologies. These autonomous fleets are more cost-effective and could replace up to 6.2 million drivers worldwide by 2030 84. In the case of driverless car-sharing systems, AI systems can be used to predict the charging and/or maintenance needs of shared vehicles, ensuring user reliability and safety, and reducing unexpected downtime 85, as well as helping cities to properly distribute vehicles throughout the territory 86.

Dynamic pricing: AI in mobility platforms, such as TVDE, has enabled the implementation of dynamic pricing systems 87. These systems automatically adjust trip prices in real time, based on demand, traffic, weather conditions, and vehicle availability. The use of AI algorithms allows for the optimization of vehicle distribution, ensuring that supply quickly responds to demand fluctuations. Additionally, AI analyzes large volumes of data to predict peak demand times, proactively adjusting prices and ensuring a more efficient allocation of available resources.
learning_objective: Explain how AI-powered shared mobility systems use data and algorithms to optimize vehicle matching, route planning, and dynamic pricing, and describe the resulting impacts on service efficiency, congestion, and energy consumption.
description: This lecture explores the role of AI in shared mobility systems—including cars (such as TVDE platforms), bicycles, and scooters—highlighting how mobile applications and AI-driven data collection enable more efficient, responsive, and sustainable transportation services. Topics include AI-based algorithms for matching users with vehicles, route optimization, real-time operations management, demand prediction (with an example from Tokyo’s taxi system), dynamic pricing, and the management of autonomous vehicle fleets. The lecture also examines how AI supports the prevention of fraudulent activities, personalization of user experience, and optimization of vehicle distribution and maintenance, demonstrating AI’s capacity to reduce congestion, energy consumption, and operational downtime in shared mobility networks.
lecture_outline: Shared mobility systems leverage mobile applications to collect large amounts of data, enabling AI to predict passenger demand and reduce empty trips, which helps lower congestion and energy consumption.
AI-based algorithms enable quick and effective matching between users and available vehicles or drivers, reducing waiting times and improving service efficiency.
AI tools support operators in efficiently planning itineraries, estimating travel times, predicting demand fluctuations, and suggesting destinations to drivers based on user travel history.

Dynamic pricing systems powered by AI automatically adjust trip prices in real time based on demand, traffic, weather, and vehicle availability, optimizing vehicle distribution and resource allocation.

In autonomous and driverless car-sharing systems, AI predicts vehicle charging and maintenance needs, ensures reliability and safety, and assists in the proper distribution of vehicles across urban areas.

content_pt:
Existem  muitas  aplicações  onde  a  IA  pode  ter  um grande impacto no mercado ferroviário 88 , permitindo melhorar os atrasos na chegada de comboios, reduzir os custos de manutenção tradicionais de comboios e da infraestrutura, e melhorar a experiência do cliente 89 . O aumento do número de dispositivos IoT, a

disponibilidade de dados e a capacidade computacional  (juntamente com  a  redução dos custos da tecnologia) criam as condições ideais para a aplicação de técnicas de IA neste mercado.

Condução e o controlo autónomo 90 : ao contrário das estradas, a operação automática de comboios é uma realidade  há  quase  40  anos.  O  primeiro  metro  sem condutor  do  mundo  entrou  em  funcionamento  na cidade  francesa  de  Lille,  em  1983.  A  automação refere-se ao processo em que a responsabilidade pela gestão da operação é transferida do condutor para o sistema de controlo do comboio. Algoritmos capazes de  tomar  decisões  em  tempo  real  e  conectados permitem  a  automatização  do  funcionamento  dos transportes  em  condições  de  seg urança 91 .  Existem vários  níveis  de  automação,  definidos  conforme  as funções operacionais são atribuídas ao pessoal ou ao sistema. Por exemplo, o Grau de Automação 0 corresponde à operação à vista, como num elétrico no trânsito urbano. O Grau de Automação 4 refere -se a  veículos  totalmente  automáticos,  sem  qualquer tripulação a bordo. Estes sistemas são usados principalmente em linhas de metro, onde as redes são menos complexas e costumam operar com comboios idênticos.  Graças  ao  sistema  de  túneis,  trata -se  de uma infraestrutura fechada com influências externas controladas. De acordo com a International Association  of  Public  Transport (UITP),  no  final  de 2020,  existiam  linhas  de  metro  totalmente  auto -matizadas  em  48  cidades,  que  vão  de  Salvador  no Brasil, a Singapura, passando  por  Barcelona  ou Budapeste.  O  número  total  de  linhas  com  Grau  de Automação 4 (GoA4) aumentou de 62 para 80 entre 2017 e 2020. Metros totalmente automatizados

metros/.

representaram 10% da nova infraestrutura de metro nesse período e 8% do total até ao final de 2020 92 .

Roteamento e programação inteligentes: tal como no transporte rodoviário, a recolha de dados e o uso de algoritmos  de  IA  permitem  ajudar  a  analisar  dados relacionados com rotas de viagem, comportamento de peões e passageiros, mitigação do uso de energia, p oluição, congestionamento de tráfego e bem como melhorar a segurança dos passageiros. São várias as propostas de utilização de IA, que têm passado por aplicações de machine learning na previsão de fluxo urbano 93 , na definição de horários dos comboios 94 , na identificação  de  padrões  de  atraso  para  estimar  os níveis  de  atraso  tanto  para  as  linhas  ferroviárias  de passageiros  como  para  as  redes  de  transporte  de mercadorias 95 ; da mesma forma que se tem proposto a utilização de big data para sistemas ferroviários inteligentes 96 , assim defendido o potencial da otimização por enxame de partículas para ferrovias 97 .

Por  exemplo,  a  Deutsche  Bahn  alemã  implementou sistemas  de  IA  na  operação  de  certos  comboios regionais,  capazes  de  responder  adequadamente  a imprevistos e irregularidades e, por exemplo, adaptar e decidir em frações de segundo qual o comboio que deve  passar  primeiro  por  uma  secção 98 .  Durante  a pandemia, o Metro do Panamá usou IA para fornecer às operadoras e autoridades de transporte ferramentas avançadas de gestão do fluxo de passageiros.  A  solução  permite  que  os  operadores ajustem a sua oferta de forma simples e em tempo real, em c onformidade com os diversos protocolos de distanciamento social e para evitar concentrações de

Manutenção  preditiva  e  gestão  de  ativos:  vem -se consolidando a tendência para passar da manutenção corretiva ou preventiva para a preditiva, a  fim  de  reduzir  os  custos  globais  de  manutenção. Essencialmente, dada a quantidade de novos dados disponíveis, o objetivo é avançar para métodos orientados  por dados  que  se  baseiam  em  dados históricos e/ou em tempo real, a fim de diagnosticar falhas 100 e defeitos 101 para os poder prever e evitar 102 , recomendando intervenções de manutenção e melhoria,  melhorando  o  desempenho  dos  ativos  e reduzindo os custos e o tempo de inatividade 103 .  As técnicas  de  IA  permitem  que  os  engenheiros  de manutenção realizem atividades de inspeção e diagnóstico  de  forma  mais  eficiente  em  termos  de custos,  tempo  e  precisão  na  deteção  de  avarias, apoiando também  o planeamento dinâmico de atividades e a automatização da manutenção 104 .  Em Portugal,  por  exemplo,  está  a  desenvolver se  um -projeto,  denominado ScanCAT, que visa potenciar a utilização de tecnologias de IA na deteção de anomalias em isoladores de catenária com recurso a videografia 105 . A União Europeia atribuiu mais de 2,3 mil  milhões  de  euros  para  o  desenvolvimento  de transportes inteligentes, verdes e integrados no período de 2014 2020, -no âmbito da Iniciativa Horizonte 2020 106 . Esta iniciativa inclui vários projetos de investigação relacionados com a aplicação de IA em  sistemas  de  transporte,  incluindo  o  programa Shift2Rail que é a primeira iniciativa ferroviária

europeia focada na inovação e desenvolvimento  de soluções  orientadas  para  o  mercado,  através  da aceleração  da  integração  de  novas  e  avançadas tecnologias  em  pro dutos  e  soluções  inovadoras  no contexto do transporte ferroviário 107 .
content_en:
There are many applications where AI can have a major impact on the railway market 88, enabling improvements in train arrival delays, reducing traditional maintenance costs for trains and infrastructure, and enhancing the customer experience 89. The increase in the number of IoT devices, the availability of data, and computational capacity (along with the reduction in technology costs) create ideal conditions for the application of AI techniques in this market.

Autonomous driving and control 90: unlike roads, automatic train operation has been a reality for almost 40 years. The world's first driverless metro began operating in the French city of Lille in 1983. Automation refers to the process in which responsibility for managing operations is transferred from the driver to the train control system. Algorithms capable of making real-time decisions and being connected enable the automation of transport operations under safe conditions 91. There are various levels of automation, defined according to whether operational functions are assigned to staff or the system. For example, Grade of Automation 0 corresponds to visual operation, as in a tram in urban traffic. Grade of Automation 4 refers to fully automatic vehicles, with no crew on board. These systems are mainly used on metro lines, where networks are less complex and usually operate with identical trains. Thanks to the tunnel system, it is a closed infrastructure with controlled external influences. According to the International Association of Public Transport (UITP), at the end of 2020, there were fully automated metro lines in 48 cities, ranging from Salvador in Brazil to Singapore, including Barcelona and Budapest. The total number of lines with Grade of Automation 4 (GoA4) increased from 62 to 80 between 2017 and 2020. Fully automated metros represented 10% of new metro infrastructure in that period and 8% of the total by the end of 2020 92.

Intelligent routing and scheduling: as in road transport, data collection and the use of AI algorithms help analyze data related to travel routes, pedestrian and passenger behavior, energy use mitigation, pollution, traffic congestion, and also improve passenger safety. There are several proposals for the use of AI, including machine learning applications for urban flow prediction 93, train timetable definition 94, identification of delay patterns to estimate delay levels for both passenger rail lines and freight transport networks 95; similarly, the use of big data for intelligent railway systems 96 has been proposed, as well as the potential of particle swarm optimization for railways 97.

For example, German Deutsche Bahn has implemented AI systems in the operation of certain regional trains, capable of responding appropriately to unforeseen events and irregularities and, for example, adapting and deciding in fractions of a second which train should pass first through a section 98. During the pandemic, the Panama Metro used AI to provide operators and transport authorities with advanced passenger flow management tools. The solution allows operators to adjust their offer simply and in real time, in compliance with various social distancing protocols and to avoid crowding, which arose due to the Covid-19 pandemic 99.

Predictive maintenance and asset management: the trend is consolidating to move from corrective or preventive maintenance to predictive maintenance, in order to reduce overall maintenance costs. Essentially, given the amount of new data available, the goal is to move towards data-driven methods based on historical and/or real-time data to diagnose failures 100 and defects 101 so they can be predicted and avoided 102, recommending maintenance and improvement interventions, improving asset performance, and reducing costs and downtime 103. AI techniques allow maintenance engineers to carry out inspection and diagnosis activities more efficiently in terms of cost, time, and accuracy in fault detection, also supporting dynamic activity planning and maintenance automation 104. In Portugal, for example, a project called ScanCAT is being developed, which aims to enhance the use of AI technologies in the detection of anomalies in catenary insulators using videography 105. The European Union allocated more than 2.3 billion euros for the development of smart, green, and integrated transport in the period 2014-2020, under the Horizon 2020 Initiative 106. This initiative includes several research projects related to the application of AI in transport systems, including the Shift2Rail program, which is the first European railway initiative focused on innovation and the development of market-oriented solutions, by accelerating the integration of new and advanced technologies into innovative products and solutions in the context of railway transport 107.
learning_objective: Explain how AI applications such as autonomous train operation, intelligent routing and scheduling, and predictive maintenance are transforming the railway ecosystem and other guided transport systems.
description: This lecture explores the transformative role of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in railway ecosystems and other guided transport systems, focusing on real-world applications that improve efficiency, safety, and customer experience. It examines how advancements in IoT, data availability, and computational power have enabled AI-driven solutions in three key areas: autonomous train operation with varying grades of automation—including fully automated metro lines; intelligent routing and scheduling to optimize train timetables, passenger flows, and energy use; and predictive maintenance leveraging data-driven diagnostics to reduce costs and system downtime. Case studies, such as Deutsche Bahn’s adaptive train operations and AI-powered passenger flow management in the Panama Metro, illustrate current implementations. The lecture also highlights European initiatives like Shift2Rail and Horizon 2020, underscoring ongoing research and investment in smart, integrated transport.
lecture_outline: AI enables improvements in train arrival delays, reduces maintenance costs, and enhances the customer experience in the railway market.

Autonomous train operation uses algorithms and varying automation grades to transfer operational responsibility from drivers to control systems, with fully automated metros now present in 48 cities worldwide.
Intelligent routing and scheduling apply AI and data analysis to optimize route planning, predict urban flow, define timetables, and respond to unforeseen events, improving safety and efficiency.

Predictive maintenance uses AI-driven, data-based methods to diagnose and predict failures, reduce costs and downtime, and support efficient asset management, as seen in projects like ScanCAT and EU initiatives such as Shift2Rail.

O transporte marítimo e as operações portuárias têm assistido  a  uma  grande  transformação  nos  últimos anos, na qual as tecnologias de Big Data , IoT , blockchain e de IA 108 têm tido um papel considerável. Entre as principais tendências encontramos o crescimento do tráfego dos contentores e concomitante necessidade de adaptação dos portos, o  aumento  do  tráfego  marítimo  e  dos  riscos  de segurança (na dupla vertente de safety & security ), ou o aumento da dimensão dos navios e da pressão que exercem sobre as envolventes portuárias. O aumento da  consciência  ambiental  impôs  a  obrigação  de adaptação a regras mais ecológicas no contexto de uma concorrência internacional feroz no ecossistema m arítimo mundial.

Entre  as  aplicações  de  IA  neste  mercado,  podemos encontrar:

Navegação autónoma: tal como nos restantes mercados,  também  nos  transportes  marítimo  e  por vias navegáveis interiores, se tem avançado na automatização da navegação através de sistemas de

IA. Os Unmanned Surface Vehicles (USV) são veículos autónomos que operam na superfície da água sem guarnição 109 . Utilizando sistemas de decisão automatizados a bordo e controlados remotamente, os navios autónomos podem operar de forma independente durante  viagens 110 . Em 2018, a RollsRoyce  e  o  operador  de  ferry  finlandês Finferries apresentaram um ferry totalmente autónomo chamado Falco, concebido para percorrer pequenos trechos e monitorizado por um operador a cerca de 50 quilómetros  de  distância  durante  a  demonstração inicial da sua autonomia 111 . Outro projeto atualmente em curso é o Yara Birkeland, um navio porta -contentores de 80 metros de comprimento concebido para transportar fertilizantes em viagens autónomas e

totalmente alimentado por eletricidade 112 . A UE está atualmente  a  financiar  o  projeto  AUTOSHIP  para desenvolver dois navios autónomos um -para o transporte marítimo de curta distância e outro para as vias navegáveis interiores 113 .

Otimização das operações a bordo de embarcações: os  dados  sobre  o  desempenho  dos  navios  e  os sistemas  de  navegação podem ajudar as empresas de transporte marítimo a monitorizar o desempenho dos navios e a tomar as medidas necessárias para melhorar a eficiência operacional dos navios 114 . A IA tem sido utilizada para melhorar o auxílio à tomada de decisão e a eficiência da navegação e demais operações  a  bordo  pela  tripulação,  analisando  em

tempo  real variáveis como  correntes, condições meteorológicas  e  de  mar,  e  velocidade  através  da água. Por exemplo, algumas empresas têm desenvolvido sistemas de bordo baseados em IA que permitem otimizar a operação dos navios, designadamente de ferries, contribuindo significativamente para um aumento da consciência situacional,  redução  do  consumo  de  combustível  e emissões 115 . A  otimização  da  velocidade  tem  sido utilizada  para  aumentar  a  eficiência  energética  dos navios  que  transportam  mercadorias  e  passageiros entre portos específicos 116 .

Gestão  de  Tráfego  Marítimo  e  em  Vias  Navegáveis Interiores:  sistemas  de  monitorização  do  tráfego  de navios e serviços de informação fluvial (RIS) 117 baseados  em  IA  processam  dados  de  sensores, radares e sistemas de identificação automática (AIS) para  controlar  o  tráfego  e  prevenir  acidentes,  bem como otimizar  rotas  e  prever  atrasos  causados  por condições meteorológicas adversas ou congestionamento de tráfego 118 . Para além da otimização  da  velocidade,  a  eficiência  energética pode ser alcançada através do planeamento inteligente  das  rotas  marítimas.  Um  modelo  híbrido melhorado  para  o  planeamento  inteligente  de  rotas marítimas através de algoritmos genéticos demons trou as possibilidades de otimização do consumo de energia no planeamento de rotas marítimas 119 .  Uma parceria entre a Orient Overseas Container Line (OOCL) e a Microsoft tem permitido à OOCL utilizar o grande volume de dados gerados pela

sua frota para poder prever melhor quando é que os navios  vão  chegar  ao  cais,  coordenando  melhor  a atividade portuária 120 . O projeto  MAP-BORealis  da Drift&Noise  utiliza  dados  de  satélite  para  otimizar  a rota  através  do  Oceano  Ártico  e  poupar  tempo  e recursos 121 .

Prevenção e Gestão de Acidentes: a IA melhora a segurança ao detetar anomalias nas operações marítimas, facilitando a gestão de acidentes e riscos ambientais. Sistemas de reconhecimento de imagem e monitorização contínuo ajudam a identificar navios mesmo q uando os transmissores AIS estão desligados 122 . O projeto Orca AI visa fornecer sistemas de assistência para portos e navios offshore, combinando dados de sensores de câmaras térmicas e de ultra baixa -luminosidade para acrescentar reconhecimento de imagem a sistemas de posicionamento e radares marítimos. Este reconheci -mento de imagem é alimentado por um algoritmo de machine  learning permitindo evitar colisões e a sobrecarga de informação na ponte do navio quando navega em vias navegáveis movimentadas 123 .

Manutenção  preditiva  e  gestão  de  ativos:  também aqui se assiste à tendência para passar da manutenção corretiva ou preventiva para a preditiva. A tecnologia

de IA pode utilizar dados históricos para determinar intervalos de manutenção e prever o estado de peças individuais ou de sistemas inteiros e avaliar o nível de

manutenção de que irão necessitar. O Expert Insight da Wärtsilä é um sistema que monitoriza os motores dos  navios  do  fabricante  finlandês  e  foi  concebido para  prestar  assistência  proactiva  às  equipas  de manutenção 124 .

Operações Portuárias Inteligentes: Portos inteligentes utilizam IA para otimizar o uso de guindastes e veículos,  planear  a  disponibilidade  de  atracação  e realizar a manutenção preditiva dos equipamentos 125 . Exemplos  incluem  a  plataforma  de  otimização  de escalas no porto de Roterdão, que reduz o tempo de espera dos naviose melhora a eficiência energética 126 ou a utilização da rede 5G pelo Porto de Aveiro para monitorizar e gerir a suas operações em tempo real 127 . O porto de Antuérpia também está a experimentar um sistema  que  utiliza  dados  AIS  e  câmaras  adicionais para localizar a posição dos navios no porto e otimizar o fluxo de tráfego e evitar congestionamentos 128 .

Vigilância marítima: a vigilância marítima dá apoio a políticas  de  segurança marítima e de verificação de abastecimento ilegal de combustível 129 . A IA está a ser usada nos sistemas de vigilância  visual 130 .  Modelos de redes neuronais  baseadas em deep  learning melhoram a precisão do reconhecimento visual e da verificação de navios  marítimos.  Por  exemplo,  o projeto  FOCUS  EYE  da  Mitsui  OSK  Lines 131 cujo sistema reconhece os navios com precisão utilizando câmaras de alta resolução e uma  unidade de processamento gráfico. O Porto de Singapura e a IBM

content_en:
Maritime transport and port operations have undergone a major transformation in recent years, in which Big Data, IoT, blockchain, and AI technologies have played a considerable role. Among the main trends are the growth of container traffic and the consequent need for ports to adapt, the increase in maritime traffic and security risks (in both safety & security aspects), and the increase in ship size and the pressure they exert on port environments. The rise in environmental awareness has imposed the obligation to adapt to greener rules in the context of fierce international competition in the global maritime ecosystem.

Among the AI applications in this market, we can find:

Autonomous navigation: As in other markets, maritime and inland waterway transport have also advanced in navigation automation through AI systems. Unmanned Surface Vehicles (USVs) are autonomous vehicles that operate on the water surface without crew. Using automated decision systems onboard and remote control, autonomous ships can operate independently during voyages. In 2018, Rolls-Royce and the Finnish ferry operator Finferries presented a fully autonomous ferry called Falco, designed to cover short distances and monitored by an operator about 50 kilometers away during the initial demonstration of its autonomy. Another ongoing project is the Yara Birkeland, an 80-meter-long container ship designed to transport fertilizers on autonomous journeys and fully powered by electricity. The EU is currently funding the AUTOSHIP project to develop two autonomous ships—one for short sea shipping and another for inland waterways.

Optimization of onboard vessel operations: Data on ship performance and navigation systems can help shipping companies monitor ship performance and take necessary measures to improve operational efficiency. AI has been used to enhance decision support and navigation efficiency, as well as other onboard operations by the crew, analyzing in real time variables such as currents, weather and sea conditions, and speed through water. For example, some companies have developed AI-based onboard systems that optimize ship operations, particularly ferries, significantly contributing to increased situational awareness, reduced fuel consumption, and emissions. Speed optimization has been used to increase the energy efficiency of ships transporting goods and passengers between specific ports.

Maritime and Inland Waterway Traffic Management: AI-based ship traffic monitoring systems and River Information Services (RIS) process data from sensors, radars, and Automatic Identification Systems (AIS) to control traffic and prevent accidents, as well as optimize routes and predict delays caused by adverse weather conditions or traffic congestion. In addition to speed optimization, energy efficiency can be achieved through intelligent maritime route planning. An improved hybrid model for intelligent maritime route planning using genetic algorithms has demonstrated the possibilities of optimizing energy consumption in maritime route planning. A partnership between Orient Overseas Container Line (OOCL) and Microsoft has enabled OOCL to use the large volume of data generated by its fleet to better predict when ships will arrive at the dock, better coordinating port activity. The MAP-BORealis project by Drift&Noise uses satellite data to optimize the route through the Arctic Ocean, saving time and resources.

Accident Prevention and Management: AI improves safety by detecting anomalies in maritime operations, facilitating accident and environmental risk management. Image recognition and continuous monitoring systems help identify ships even when AIS transmitters are off. The Orca AI project aims to provide assistance systems for ports and offshore ships, combining data from thermal and ultra-low-light cameras to add image recognition to positioning systems and maritime radars. This image recognition is powered by a machine learning algorithm, allowing collision avoidance and reducing information overload on the ship's bridge when navigating busy waterways.

Predictive maintenance and asset management: Here too, there is a trend to move from corrective or preventive maintenance to predictive maintenance. AI technology can use historical data to determine maintenance intervals and predict the condition of individual parts or entire systems and assess the level of maintenance they will require. Wärtsilä's Expert Insight is a system that monitors the engines of the Finnish manufacturer's ships and was designed to provide proactive assistance to maintenance teams.

Smart Port Operations: Smart ports use AI to optimize the use of cranes and vehicles, plan berth availability, and perform predictive maintenance on equipment. Examples include the optimization platform for ship calls at the Port of Rotterdam, which reduces ship waiting times and improves energy efficiency, or the use of the 5G network by the Port of Aveiro to monitor and manage its operations in real time. The Port of Antwerp is also experimenting with a system that uses AIS data and additional cameras to locate the position of ships in the port and optimize traffic flow and avoid congestion.

Maritime surveillance: Maritime surveillance supports maritime security policies and the verification of illegal fuel supply. AI is being used in visual surveillance systems. Deep learning-based neural network models improve the accuracy of visual recognition and verification of maritime vessels. For example, the FOCUS EYE project by Mitsui OSK Lines, whose system accurately recognizes ships using high-resolution cameras and a graphics processing unit. The Port of Singapore and IBM are collaborating on a project called SAFER, which uses a machine learning approach to predict ship arrival times, potential traffic hotspots, unusual ship behaviors, and illegal fuel supply. In Portugal, the first Technological Free Zone (ZLT Infante D. Henrique) recognized by the Portuguese Government will test, in open sea and real circumstances, unmanned security and defense systems and other technologies, in subsurface, surface (land and wet), and aerial environments.
learning_objective: Explain how AI technologies such as autonomous navigation, predictive maintenance, and smart port operations are transforming maritime and inland waterway transport, including their implications for efficiency, safety, and environmental sustainability within the port ecosystem.
description: This lecture explores the transformative impact of AI and related digital technologies—such as Big Data, IoT, and blockchain—on the port ecosystem, maritime transport, and inland waterways. Participants will examine key trends including the growth of container and maritime traffic, increased security and environmental pressures, and the need for ports to adapt in a globally competitive landscape. The session highlights concrete AI applications such as autonomous navigation (e.g., unmanned ships like the Yara Birkeland and Falco), optimization of vessel operations, AI-driven maritime traffic management, accident prevention through advanced monitoring, predictive maintenance, smart port operations, and enhanced maritime surveillance. Real-world projects and case studies illustrate how AI improves efficiency, safety, environmental sustainability, and operational decision-making in maritime and inland waterway contexts. This lecture provides urban mobility professionals with a foundational understanding of how AI is reshaping maritime transport, informing responsible planning and collaboration in the evolving mobility sector.
lecture_outline: AI technologies such as autonomous navigation enable unmanned ships and ferries to operate independently, exemplified by projects like Falco and Yara Birkeland, contributing to operational efficiency and reducing the need for onboard crew.

AI-based optimization of onboard vessel operations and speed enhances decision support, situational awareness, and energy efficiency, leading to lower fuel consumption and emissions in maritime transport.

AI-driven traffic management and route planning systems process sensor and AIS data to prevent accidents, optimize routes, predict delays, and improve coordination of port activities, increasing safety and efficiency.

Predictive maintenance powered by AI uses historical data to forecast equipment needs, as seen in systems like Wärtsilä's Expert Insight, allowing proactive asset management and minimizing unplanned downtime.

Smart port operations leverage AI to optimize crane and vehicle use, plan berth availability, and perform predictive maintenance, as demonstrated by the Port of Rotterdam and Port of Aveiro, enhancing efficiency and supporting environmental sustainability.

Sistemas de Bilhética inteligentes:  Em  particular  no transporte público, os sistemas de bilhética inteligentes  e  integrados,  alimentados  por  IA,  têm melhorado significativamente a experiência dos utilizadores. Estes sistemas utilizam dados de diferentes  fo ntes para prever a procura e ajustar a oferta de serviços em tempo real, reunindo informação  e  serviços  de  mobilidade  num  único espaço. Além disso, permitem a implementação de tarifas  dinâmicas,  que  podem  incentivar  o  uso  do transporte público fora dos hor ários de pico, distribuindo melhor a lotação e reduzindo a superlotação 133 .

Planeamento urbano e infraestruturas: O planeamento de transportes tem como  objetivo identificar as necessidades da comunidade e decidir sobre  a melhor  abordagem  para  satisfazer  essa procura,  considerando  simultaneamente  o  impacto social, ambiental e económico. Já na década de 90 se utilizavam redes neuronais  para o planeamento, conceção  e  modelação  de  vias  de  trânsito. No entanto,  a  capacidade  de  aceder  a  uma  enorme quantidade de dados e utilizar algoritmos avançados de aprendizagem automática trouxe novas possibilidades ao planeamento urbano e dos sistemas de transporte, que têm registado um crescimento  significativo 134 . Nos últimos 20 anos, com o surgimento de tecnologias de IA  capazes  de analisar dados gerados pelos utilizadores e veículos, foram  desenvolvidos  vários  sistemas  de  informação para logística, roteamento, mapeamento e planeamento. Esses sistemas melhoraram a capacidade  de processar dados, permitindo um planeamento mais eficiente do transporte e levando à criação  e  desenvolvimento  de  diversos  ITS.  A  IA  é utilizada para desenhar redes que respondem adequadamente  às  necessidades  da  comunidade, facilitando melho rias e expansões nas infraestruturas existentes e melhorando a eficiência 135 .

Integração da gestão de infraestruturas: Plataformas e serviços desenvolvidos a partir  de tecnologias de  IA podem ser cruciais  para  agregar  e  processar  dados em  tempo  real  sobre  os  operadores  de  diferentes tipos de redes de infraestrutura (transporte rodoviário, ferroviário  e  outros  sistemas  de  transporte  guiado, marítimo, por vias navegáveis interiores, aéreo, e até mesmo do setor elétrico ou infraestruturas digitais). Esta integração permite uma gestão eficiente e uma resposta  mais  articulada  a  situações  de  crise  ou necessidade 136 .

Mobility as a Service (MaaS): O conceito de Mobilidade  como  um  Serviço  (MaaS)  surgiu  com  o aumento dos serviços de transporte nas cidades, para designar um sistema inovador capaz de combinar de forma inteligente e eficiente vários modos de transporte, oferecendo serviços de mobilidade adaptados  às necessidades  das pessoas 137 . Por exemplo, o Whim, uma aplicação lançada em Helsínquia  em  2015,  integra  serviços  como  trans -portes públicos, táxis, partilha de bicicletas e aluguer de automóveis. O Kyyti, também da Finlândia, oferece uma plataforma de transportes responsiva à procur a, que permite planear e reservar soluções personalizadas  para  municípios  e  operadores  de transporte 138 . Um  sistema MaaS  inteligente pode oferecer  soluções  mais  sustentáveis  do  que  outras soluções  de  transporte  desagregadas,  tornando  as deslocações mais convenientes e oferecendo serviços de mobilidade flexíveis, económicos, fiáveis e sustentáveis. A utilização de IA ajuda a desenvolver e gerir serviços de mobilidade avançados, aproveitando os dados de localização e tempo registados  frequentemente  por  dispositivos  como smartphones, veículos de micromobilidade (que motivaram  aliás,  da  parte  da  AMT, a  emissão  de Linhas de Orientação sobre a Regulação da Micromobilidade Partilhada 139 ), computadores de bordo de veículos ou sistemas de navegação baseados  em  aplicações,  e  poderá  ter  um  papel decisivo em garantir o compromisso com os objetivos de sustentabilidade 140 .

content_en:
Intelligent Ticketing Systems: Particularly in public transport, intelligent and integrated ticketing systems powered by AI have significantly improved user experience. These systems use data from different sources to predict demand and adjust service supply in real time, bringing together mobility information and services in a single space. Additionally, they enable the implementation of dynamic fares, which can encourage the use of public transport outside peak hours, better distributing occupancy and reducing overcrowding 133.

Urban Planning and Infrastructure: Transport planning aims to identify community needs and decide on the best approach to meet that demand, while simultaneously considering social, environmental, and economic impact. As early as the 1990s, neural networks were used for the planning, design, and modeling of traffic routes. However, the ability to access a huge amount of data and use advanced machine learning algorithms has brought new possibilities to urban and transport system planning, which has seen significant growth 134. In the last 20 years, with the emergence of AI technologies capable of analyzing data generated by users and vehicles, several information systems for logistics, routing, mapping, and planning have been developed. These systems have improved data processing capacity, enabling more efficient transport planning and leading to the creation and development of various ITS. AI is used to design networks that adequately respond to community needs, facilitating improvements and expansions in existing infrastructure and improving efficiency 135.

Integration of Infrastructure Management: Platforms and services developed from AI technologies can be crucial for aggregating and processing real-time data on operators of different types of infrastructure networks (road, rail, and other guided transport systems, maritime, inland waterways, air, and even the electricity sector or digital infrastructure). This integration enables efficient management and a more coordinated response to crisis situations or needs 136.

'Micro.ai - Infrastructure', available online at [accessed on 12/08/2024].

Mobility as a Service (MaaS): The concept of Mobility as a Service (MaaS) emerged with the increase in transport services in cities, to designate an innovative system capable of intelligently and efficiently combining various modes of transport, offering mobility services tailored to people's needs 137. For example, Whim, an application launched in Helsinki in 2015, integrates services such as public transport, taxis, bike sharing, and car rental. Kyyti, also from Finland, offers a transport platform responsive to demand, allowing planning and booking of customized solutions for municipalities and transport operators 138. An intelligent MaaS system can offer more sustainable solutions than other disaggregated transport solutions, making travel more convenient and offering flexible, economical, reliable, and sustainable mobility services. The use of AI helps to develop and manage advanced mobility services, leveraging location and time data frequently recorded by devices such as smartphones, micromobility vehicles (which, in fact, led AMT to issue Guidelines on Shared Micromobility Regulation 139), vehicle onboard computers, or app-based navigation systems, and may play a decisive role in ensuring commitment to sustainability goals 140.
